title: TSX slips on disappointing Rogers outlook, weak energy sector
text:
© Reuters. A man walks past an old Toronto Stock Exchange sign in Toronto

(Reuters) - Canada's main stock index fell on Wednesday, pressured by a dour revenue forecast from Rogers Communications and a drop in energy shares, with losses limited by gains in material stocks.

* At 9:56 a.m. ET (13:56 GMT), the Toronto Stock Exchange's S&P/TSX composite index ( ) was down 19.9 points, or 0.18%, at 16,371.62.

* Rogers Communications Inc (TO: ) fell 6% after lowering its full-year revenue forecast, triggering a 2% decline in the communication services index ( ).

* The energy sector ( ) slipped 0.7%, as U.S. crude ( ) prices declined 0.9% a barrel, while Brent crude ( ) lost 0.7%. [O/R]

* The financials sector ( ) dipped 0.1%, while the consumer index ( ) fell about half a percent.

* The materials sector ( ), which includes precious and base metals miners, was among the few bright spots, up 1% as rose 0.3% to $1,486.4 an ounce. [GOL/] ]

* On the TSX, 111 issues were higher, while 109 issues declined for a 1.02-to-1 ratio favouring gainers, with 12.51 million shares traded.

* The largest percentage gainers on the TSX were Eldorado Gold (TO: ), which jumped 4.2%, and Agnico Eagle Miners (TO: ), which rose 2.5%.

* The most heavily traded shares by volume were Aurora Cannabis (TO: ), Rogers Communications (TO: ) and Zenabis Gllobal Inc (TO: ).

* The TSX posted two new 52-week highs and four new lows.

* Across all Canadian issues there were five new 52-week highs and 13 new lows, with total volume of 22.23 million shares.
description: TSX slips on disappointing Rogers outlook, weak energy sector
